instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.TPS51980: What is TPS51980? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1286 Macbook Pros,  A1297 Macbook Pros,  A1369 Macbook Airs,  A1466 Macbook Airs,  A1370 Macbook Airs,  and A1465 Macbook Airs.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PPVCC_S0_CPU: What is PPVCC_S0_CPU? The "PPVCC_S0_CPU" power rail is responsible for supplying power to the CPU when the MacBook is fully on, or in the S0 state. This rail is one of the main voltages that the CPU requires for operation. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Board with supposedly no water damage. I cleaned some corrosion from inside the thunderbolt ports. I found some corrosion near one of the debug connectors, so I removed it. Later I thought it may be a BIOS Issue so I replaced the bios chip.

Initially this board had an orange light (no battery), and the fan would power on for a second or two, turn off, and then repeat. I searched the board and found that the S5 rails were constant while the S0 rails were ALL turning on and off. Otherwise those rails seemed to be exactly as expected. I've checked every current sensing resistor I could find, thinking it was a sensor issue. After a week or so of troubleshooting, the fan no longer spins up. I left it whilst doing the spin-up routine for 10 minutes, came back, and now I'm here.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12.5V along with all the <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5</SIGNAL> rails.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 0.9v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41v



The weirdest thing that made me sign up for this forum is that the F7005 18.5V fuse has 0.1ohm resistance, yet has 0V on both sides when plugged in. If I test the pins on the DC Jack connector, they all come back as 0 volts. So either something is terribly wrong or I might just have the secret for infinite energy.

Any advice? I'm now looking to troubleshoot the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> circuitry to see if maybe it's responsible for my <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> problems.

I have the board view, schematic, a donor board, a basic microscope/iron/air station and so forth.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: It is of course not possible to have <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and not have power going in to F7005, assuming you have no battery plugged in. Go back and check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
Alas, the screw hole I was using as a ground was not properly grounding! The fuse has voltage (16.5v)
Still, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is .105v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is missing.
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is .105v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL> is missing
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> is 0.415v 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> is 12.5v

I see that <CHIP>U7200</CHIP> seems to input <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S5_HS_COMPUTING</SIGNAL> and outputs <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>
<CHIP>U7200</CHIP> VIN is 12.5v, yet VDD is 0v

so is <CHIP>ISL95826</CHIP> potentially bad? Or are there any major other sensors I should first investigate?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: You have no S5 voltage so that is where it ends right away. What is <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4707"]You have no S5 voltage so that is where it ends right away. What is <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>?[/QUOTE]
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> is 3.398V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>? If not low then <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> is dead.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4729"]Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>? If not low then <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> is dead.[/QUOTE]
Resistance appears to be huge, and measuring capacitance shows ~10uF (same as <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR>). So should I run a wire from <CAPACITOR>C7505</CAPACITOR> to pin 29 on <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP>?

I replaced <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> from a donor and got the same result except that <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> was 1.4V.

Re-seated the chip for good measure and now it's doing what it was doing before (fan stops and starts). The resistance of <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> is now 1.9M ohm.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> and all other s0 rails appear to be pulsing along with the fan. This was the original issue before I lost <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> altogether.


If you think <CHIP>TPS51980</CHIP> from donor is bad (only revived by heating) then I can order some "new."

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
Okay So <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> is pulsing, <SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> is constant, as is <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>. So the 3.3v/5v power supply is functioning correctly.
This board doesn't have a 3.3v current sensing circuit, so perhaps the switching circuit - if it has one?
I am aware that quarter fan spin is probably the most annoying to troubleshoot, and I've watched all rossmann videos regarding it. 

Does this seem like an RTC issue? There was initially a small amount of liquid damage on the edge of the board that contains 3 RTC crystals, along with one of the diagnostic connectors, which I had removed. Unfortunately I do not have an oscilloscope to test the clock signals.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: Is CPU Vcore pulsing too?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4773"]Is CPU Vcore pulsing too?[/QUOTE]
Yes. <SIGNAL>PPVCC_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> pulses at 0-1.755v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: Check the resistors that are in series with the data lines to the SPI ROM, all 8 of them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4805"]Check the resistors that are in series with the data lines to the SPI ROM, all 8 of them.[/QUOTE]
All resistors in the SPI Bus Series Termination section are as expected (33ohm or ~0-0.2ohm).
<RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> on the SPI ROM section is showing 0.8K instead of 3.3k, however replacing the resistor from donor yields the same result (tests 3.3k out of circuit), however, the same resistor tested at 3.3K in circuit on the donor. So the SPI rom has a resistance of only 0.786K between pins 8 and 3.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
First post says you replaced BIOS chip, what file did you flash to the chip?
You should put back the original in any case. When you have the chip out measure on diode mode all 4 data pins, 1,2,5 and 6. This way you can check if the trace to the CPU/PCH is ok and the resistors too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4812"]First post says you replaced BIOS chip, what file did you flash to the chip?
You should put back the original in any case. When you have the chip out measure on diode mode all 4 data pins, 1,2,5 and 6. This way you can check if the trace to the CPU/PCH is ok and the resistors too.[/QUOTE]

I personally did not flash anything to the ROM. I purchase them pre-flashed for this particular model. Same way I normally remove EFI lock.
And I may have fucked up and lost the original ROM chip. I'll see if I can find it.
Continuity from pin to nearest component checks out on all pins. Pins 1, 5, and 6 give me ~1.3V in diode mode. Pin 2 gives me a little under 1.0V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: Do not ever replace ROMs like that, this will fuck up the ME region and cause all sorts of problems.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4863"]Do not ever replace ROMs like that, this will fuck up the ME region and cause all sorts of problems. [/QUOTE]
Understood. I'd still like to fix the board, even if the PCH throws a fit. This is still the same issue previously experienced using the original ROM.
Any general direction you can suggest? I am willing to waste a dozen hours studying but I am unsure which processes/chips to investigate for this Problem.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: I'd be worried about that measurement on <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR>. Only cause for that would be a bad ROM chip. Remove and measure data lines and find the original.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
No Title

[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4918"]I'd be worried about that measurement on <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR>. Only cause for that would be a bad ROM chip. Remove and measure data lines and find the original.[/QUOTE]
When I've removed the ROM, the measurement is the same: about 0.8K. I physically remove <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> and it tests at 3.3k out of circuit. I test resistance of the <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> pins on the board and my multimeter is overloaded.

Here are some of the measurements I have made. <RESISTOR>R6103</RESISTOR> (in circuit) and <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> (out of circuit) appear to be correct. <CAPACITOR>C6100</CAPACITOR> appears to be 'charging' as does any capacitor. So maybe the traces within the board are fucked up?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
Is <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> present on the board?

Hmm guess not cause the <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> would not be there, <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> is only if ROM supports quad SPI mode!

Well, if you removed the ROM then there is nothing else connected to <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> and it MUST measure 3.3K. Check <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> position for crap otherwise the issue must be inside the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 4926"]Is <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> present on the board?

Hmm guess not cause the <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> would not be there, <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> is only if ROM supports quad SPI mode!

Well, if you removed the ROM then there is nothing else connected to <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> and it MUST measure 3.3K. Check <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR> position for crap otherwise the issue must be inside the board.[/QUOTE]

Hmm. Maybe too much lead in my diet.

When originally replacing the ROM (first thing I tried, before joining this forum), I shifted some things around and I thought I had blown one of those components off the board. One of them, either <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> or <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR>, I noticed was completely missing! So I grabbed one and replaced it thinking I was fixing my fuck-up.

So most recently I've tried removing <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR>. Same issue. I've then replaced <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> and removed <RESISTOR>R6130</RESISTOR>. Same issue - albeit <RESISTOR>R6101</RESISTOR> correctly measures 3.3k.
So I've lost the original ROM and the schematic doesn't specify whether or not the board has quad SPI.

Meanwhile I'm going to be comparing with the donor to see if there's anything else I might have wrongly screwed with.

The biggest and only clue I have for this board was corrosion in the thunderbolt and USB ports. Is there a way to isolate that portion of the board? Just disconnect a resistor or fuse somewhere to cut them out of the equation so I can see if the core of the board is able to boot on its own? The Thunderbolt 15V boost regulator circuit outputs 0v, but I don't know when or if thunderbolt is expected to initialize.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: The thunderbolt and USB will probably not cause the board not to buut unless there is a hard short there. Compare the reistors around the SPI area with a donor board first!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message:
[QUOTE="dukefawks, post: 5114"]The thunderbolt and USB will probably not cause the board not to buut unless there is a hard short there. Compare the reistors around the SPI area with a donor board first![/QUOTE]

Update! I had, for the hell of it, tried the bios chip from my donor board. It booted up, fan spins OK, and gives me an error related to serial number (expected). I told the retailer the previous chip may have been defective. They sent me another. New chip does the quarter fan spin issue. So should I just buy a bios programmer and do it myself? It's a bios issue I think, yet all my proper replacements dont let it boot.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> pp5v issues (Orange light, no sound/video)
threads.message: yes, because all of these chips probably have fucked ME region which will cause issues down the line anyway. Get a programmer!
